resources.string: Copyright \u00a9 2013 - 2017 EP Studios, Inc. \nAll rights reserved.\n
You shouldn\'t just have additional codes.
Be certain there aren\'t other codes that you are overlooking.
Add-on codes must only be added to regular codes.
You should be able to code 2D or 3D mapping for this kind of ablation.
Did you supervise sedation? Sedation codes are no longer bundled with the procedure codes.
No sedation codes as sedation time was < 10 minutes.
Procedural MD should not submit sedation coding. Sedation coding must be submitted by other MD

AFB ablation includes comprehensive EP testing, including LA recording and pacing. It also includes transseptal catheterization, therefore these codes cannot be added on. Mapping codes and coding for programmed stimulation after IV drug infusion can be added. The primary code includes pulmonary vein isolation. Add code 93657 if additional ablation for AFB is done (such as linear atrial ablation) and add 93655 if a separate arrhythmia mechanism is ablated (such as focal atrial tachycardia).

It is not clear if electrophysiologic testing and mapping can be billed as additional codes to AV node ablation. Often AV node ablation is combined with device implant at the same setting and these codes should be added.

SVT ablation includes comprehensive EP testing, but can be combined with the other codes listed. Note that the SVT ablation code (93653) is used not just for supraventricular tachycardia, but for WPW ablation, atrial flutter ablation, atrial tachycardia ablation, and presumably premature atrial complex ablation. If more than one arrhythmia mechanism is ablated, add code 93655.

VT ablation includes comprehensive EP testing. Mapping codes (93609 or 93613), for reasons only known to the AMA, cannot be combined with the 93654 VT ablation code. This is unlike the AFB and SVT ablation codes. LV pacing and recording also cannot be combined with VT ablation.

The most commonly used codes for EP testing is 93620. EP testing is not coded separately if ablation is performed. Mapping can be added to EP testing codes, as well as LA pacing and recording, programmed stimulation after IV drug, etc. The two primary codes lists are the most commonly used, other rarely used codes, such as His bundle recording only (93600) are listed in the All EP Codes module, but probably should be avoided.

These codes are used for implantation of a pacemaker generator and lead(s). Use the code that corresponds to the lead(s) put in. Use 33208 and 33225 for implantation of a pacemaker with CRT (i.e. with a coronary sinus lead). These codes are also used when there is removal of a prior system (generator and leads) and replacement with new generator and leads. Do not use these codes for simple generator replacements.

A new single or dual chamber ICD with new leads is coded with the same code, 33249. Code 33225 is added to 33249 if an LV/coronary sinus lead is added. Use 93641 for DFT testing at the time of the implant. These codes are also used if an ICD system (generator and leads) is removed and replaced with a new generator and leads. Do not use these codes for simple generator replacement.

These codes are used for ICD generator replacement only. Use the primary code that is specific to the type of generator being replaced. Do not use these codes for system revisions or upgrades. A common additional code is 93641 for DFT testing during the procedure.

This module contains a grab-bag of codes, and these procedures are definitely the most difficult to code. If you are just replacing a generator, use the Replace ICD or Replace PPM modules. If you are upgrading devices, changing from PPMs to ICDs, adding leads, extracting leads, removing generators without replacement, this module should have the codes you need. The basic principle to follow is to use specific codes for what you are removing (leads or generators) and then use codes for new complete systems. Example - upgrade dual chamber PPM or ICD with CRT, old leads left in place: 33233 (removal of PPM generator only), 33249 (insert single or dual chamber ICD with leads), and 33225 (add coronary sinus lead). However there is a code (33214) to upgrade a single chamber to a dual chamber PPM. Example - upgrade single chamber PPM to PPM with CRT: 33214 (upgrade single to dual chamber PPM, includes new lead) and 33225 (add CS lead). Finally here is upgrade of single chamber ICD to ICD with CRT: 33249 (Insert new/replacement ICD with single or dual leads), 33225 (add CS lead) and 33241 (removal of ICD generator only). If you are unsure how to code something, check with your coders.

As an alternative to using the procedure oriented choices in EP Coding, the All EP Codes module allows you to pick any of the codes in any combination. This may be useful if you are doing something unusual that is not covered in the other procedure lists, or if you are very familiar with how to use the codes and just want to select from the complete list. The list is ordered by code number. By default there is NO analysis of coding in this list, though this can be turned on in Settings. It is possible to enter combinations of codes that conflict. As always, with increased freedom comes increased risk.
These are miscellaneous EP procedures and their coding is quite straightforward. Just pick the code(s) you need.

SubQ ICD codes are new and will probably be changed as the procedure becomes established. There are no real guidelines yet for using these codes. These codes are not checked for consistency when you summarize them.
Only additional codes can be saved. This group has only primary codes.
No code analysis performed in this module.
Perform analysis in All EP Codes module
Check codes in All EP Codes
Test text for the Coding Wizard.

Is this a new implant or simple generator replacement? If so exit this wizard by using the back button on your device and go directly to the appropriate module (e.g. New PPM, New ICD, Replace PPM, or Replace ICD). Otherwise go to next step.

Is this an upgrade from a single to a dual chamber pacemaker? If so use code 33214 which covers this entire procedure. If you are also adding an LV cardiac vein lead add code +33225. Exit the wizard by using the back button on your device and select codes from the Upgrade/Revision/Extraction module. Otherwise go to the next step.
So we don\'t forget, add sedation coding now.

Is this a lead revision or repair or a pocket revision without adding or removing any hardware? If so use one of the codes below and then skip forward to the final page of this wizard. Otherwise go on to the next step.

OK. We have addressed the simple scenarios. What\'s left are lead and generator removals/extractions, and device upgrades. Start off by selecting what hardware (if any) was removed, and then go to the next step.

Now if you added any hardware, code what you added. If you added a generator and leads, use the new or replacement system codes (e.g. new single chamber PPM). If you just added a lead or a generator, code for the specific device(s) you added. Then go to the next step.
Did you do anything else? If so select from the choices below. Select Finish to see a summary of your codes.
Not all devices support Unicode fonts
